<p>
<a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?tla=web" rel="me">DANIEL WEBSTER</a> TO <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?tla=hec" rel="met friend colleague">MR. CLAY</a>. 
</p><p>
January 1, <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?year=1827">1827</a>. 
</p><p>
My dear Sir, - After company went out last night, and I had 
packed up my trunk, I sat down and read your letter through. 
Probably, I should have voted against any further publication ; 
but I am now fully satisfied this will do good. The statement 
is clear, and the evidence irresistible, I am satisfied, upon my 
conscience, that the whole business originated with <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?tla=anj" rel="colleague antagonist met">General J.</a> 
himself ; whether through mistake, or from intention, I do not 
say. 
</p><p>
[<a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?tla=web" rel="me">Daniel Webster</a>]
</p>
